title: I got a letter from a law firm telling me they were retained by Wells Fargo to collect the credit card I owe for 7600.
question: The law firm demands payment in 30 days. At the same time I also got my card statement from Wells Fargo to pay the card around 1100 and due date is this coming Nov 1. Is this a conflict? I would rather pay the amount due from Wells Fargo statement.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal charges for theft,Criminal charges for identity theft,Credit card fraud
answers: Respond to the law firm letter, requesting debt validation. Request a copy of all itemized billing statements and a copy of the contract or card member agreement.

You should not be getting collection letters or other contact by debt collectors concerning the Wells Fargo account if that account is not delinquent. However, if you are behind more than a few months, the account may have been turned over to a debt collection attorney. You might want to start by contacting Wells Fargo customer service and ask them: 1) if the account was turned over to a collections attorney; and 2) whether you can still make payments directly to Wells Fargo. If the account is in default and Wells Fargo referred it to a collections attorney, you might have to deal with that attorney or firm rather than Wells Fargo. If you are sued, contact a debt collection defense attorney.

You may also want to run a set of credit reports so that you can see whether there may be items on the reports that do not correspond to your actual accounts and debts. Identity theft does occur, and it can also be resolved, but the consumer has to investigate and take the necessary steps.

This is the initial demand letter which firms sue. Which law firm is it? I handle these cases on a regular basis and it is important to talk to a local debt collection defense attorney. Most of us offer free initial consultations.

Sounds either like different credit cards or a major mess up, or the law firm is bogus and claiming funds that you do not owe. What do your past statements show? If the lawfirm is bogus or trying to claim funds not due, they may be in violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, which allows recovery by the consumer of actual damages and attorney's fees. You may need to consult your own consumer attorney to get to the bottom of this. For consumer attorneys, see naca.net
Something is quite suspicious here. You should phone Customer Service and verify that $1100 will be payment in full and ask for a written email confirmation.
